descript.abstract: This shapefile shows the outline of the ACE Basin NERR boundary. The boundary followed the description for the NERR boundary and buffer as laid out in the 1992 Final Management Plan for the ACE Basin National Estuarine Research Reserve in South Carolina (see supplemental section). The boundary was hand digitized at 1:5000 from the 2006 NAIP color infrared photography (SCDNR DOQQ electronic imagery), and then it was snapped to the 2008 Beaufort, Colleton, and Charleston county parcel layers. Where parcel layers were not present, the boundary was drawn in accordance with following guidelines established by SCDNR GIS and NERRs staff. Note: Detailed steps used to create the boundary are described in the Process Step section. 1.) Along the western border, the boundary was drawn along the creek-marsh edge of Wimbee Creek, Parrot Creek and Morgan River, passing on the inside of sandbars and small marsh islands. Where privately-owned lands were adjacent to the waterbodies, the boundary was snapped to the Beaufort parcel data layers. 2.) The southern, ocean border was snapped to the Collision Regulations (COLREGS) demarcation line data layer (U.S. Coast Guard). 3.) The northern boundary was digitized to the abandoned Seaboard Coastline Railroad. 4.) The eastern boundary was snapped to Colleton and Charleston county parcel data.In 2012, the boundary was expanded to include Botany Bay Plantation and Fig Island. They were both digitized at 1:5000 off the Charleston county GIS parcel layer.
descript.purpose: This shapefile was created to have a more accurate and detailed version of the NERR boundary that was tied to parcel layers.
descript.supplinf: The boundary for ACE Basin NERR must include "an adequate portion of the land and water areas of the natural system to approximate an ecological unit and to insure effective conservation" (15 C.F.R., Part 921.11). These areas must be discreet enough to be effectively managed, but large enough to accommodate long-term research and monitoring. The ACE Basin Reserve includes lands in Charleston, and Colleton counties, and the boundary of the Reserve is described in the ACE Basin NERR Final Management Plan as follows. Please note that the Reserve does not include uplands and wetlands now held in private ownership, unless otherwise specified in the Final Management Plan. The seaward border of the ACE Basin Reserve boundary is marked by an artificial line, the Collision Regulations or "COLREGS" line, lying between the headlands of Edisto Beach and Hunting Island. The northeastern boundary includes the marshes of South Edisto River draining the western side of Edisto Island and the following tidal stream systems: Big Bay Creek, St. Pierre Creek (Fishing, Store and Bailey Creeks), North Creek and that portion of the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway (AIWW) connecting the Dawhoo River to the South Edisto. All of Jehossee Island and further north along the South Edisto to the abandoned Seaboard Coastline Railroad (SCR) bed forms the northeast corner. The alignment of the abandoned SCR, running approximately in a southwestern direction, is a persistent dominant feature, and serves as the northern boundary up to the crossing at the Combahee River. The zone includes the entire width of the Combahee River floodplain, with Wimbee Creek as the westernmost boundary. Downstream of the former railroad alignment, the western boundary follows Wimbee Creek (including the Williman Islands) into Bull River and across the lower Coosaw River into Morgan River (including Morgan Island). The buffer zone then follows Morgan River out into St. Helena Sound across the mouth of Jenkins, Village and Coffin Creeks, and then southeastward along the shore of St. Helena Island to Harbor River. The boundary crosses Harbor River at the U.S. Highway 21 bridge to Harbor Island, including all of the marshes but excluding the upland now held in private ownership. The boundary than continues southeast across Johnson Creek, again following U.S. Highway 21, and onto Hunting Island. There, the entire area of marsh and upland owned by the state of South Carolina and managed by the Department of Parks, Recreation, and Tourism (SCDPRT) is included. The southern terminus of the COLREGS line ends at Hunting Island, thus closing the boundary of the buffer zone. At the easternmost point of the buffer zone, on Edisto Island, the marsh and upland similarly owned by the state and managed by SCDPRT as Edisto Beach State Park is also included as are all wetlands and critical areas up to Highway 174.

procstep.procdesc:
On the western border, the boundary started at the railbed and moved southeast along the southwestern shore of Wimbee Creek to Bull River. It continued along the western shore of Bull River, crossed Coosaw River, into Parrot Creek. It continued along the western shore of Parrot Creek into Morgan River. It was drawn along the northern side of Morgan River and crossed Morgan River just west of the mouth to Jenkins Creek. It was snapped to the Beaufort County parcel data along the southern side of Morgan River passed Edding Point Creek, Village Creek, and Coffin Creek into St. Helena Sound. It continued along the marsh on the western side of Helena Island down to the Highway 21 bridge. It crossed Harbor River at the bridge, wrapped around and excluded all privately owned uplands on the northeast portion of Harbor Island, and then traveled southwest along the marsh of Harbor Island and Hunting Island. All of the marsh on Harbor Island was included, but none of the private upland parcels, including the small hammock islands, which were clipped out of the NERR boundary polygon. The boundary then curved along the bottom of Hunting Island State Park, past Story River and Old House Creek to the Atlantic coast. It traveled along the beach of Hunting Island State Park until it reached the COLREGS demarcation line.
The southern border left Hunting Island State Park along the COLREGS line and continued to the tip of Edisto Beach.
The eastern boundary turned inland and moved northwest along the uplands of Edisto Beach and into Big Bay Creek. It followed the south shore of Big Bay Creek and Scott Creek, snapping to the Colleton County parcel data for the Town of Edisto Beach and Edisto Beach State Park, up to Jeremy Inlet. It then was snapped to the Charleston County parcel layer along the northern boundary of Scott Creek until it joined the Edisto Beach State Park boundary. It was snapped to the park's parcel boundary until it hit Big Bay Creek. The boundary then followed the eastern shore of Big Bay Creek northward. The NERR boundary was snapped to the privately owned uplands and wetland parcels around a peninsula called 'The Neck' and as it wound through Fishing Creek, St. Pierre Creek, Store Creek, Milton Creek, Shingle Creek, and Bailey Creek up to the South Edisto River. The boundary followed the South Edisto River north, snapping to the Charleston County parcel layer up through the Intracoastal waterway just south of SC Highway 174 Dawho Bridge. At this point, the boundary crossed the Intracoastal Waterway and followed the northeastern shore of the Dawho River to Grove Plantation, snapping to the Grove Plantation parcel data until it joined with the railbed at the northeast shore of the South Edisto River.
At the northern border, the boundary left Grove Plantation, followed the railbed to the southwestern shore of Wimbee Creek; thus completing the NERR boundary polygon.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497
dataIdInfo.idPurp: This shapefile was created to have a more accurate and detailed version of the NERR boundary that was tied to parcel layers.
dataIdInfo.idAbs: This shapefile shows the outline of the ACE Basin NERR boundary. The boundary followed the description for the NERR boundary and buffer as laid out in the 1992 Final Management Plan for the ACE Basin National Estuarine Research Reserve in South Carolina (see supplemental section). The boundary was hand digitized at 1:5000 from the 2006 NAIP color infrared photography (SCDNR DOQQ electronic imagery), and then it was snapped to the 2008 Beaufort, Colleton, and Charleston county parcel layers. Where parcel layers were not present, the boundary was drawn in accordance with following guidelines established by SCDNR GIS and NERRs staff. Note: Detailed steps used to create the boundary are described in the Process Step section. 1.) Along the western border, the boundary was drawn along the creek-marsh edge of Wimbee Creek, Parrot Creek and Morgan River, passing on the inside of sandbars and small marsh islands. Where privately-owned lands were adjacent to the waterbodies, the boundary was snapped to the Beaufort parcel data layers. 2.) The southern, ocean border was snapped to the Collision Regulations (COLREGS) demarcation line data layer (U.S. Coast Guard). 3.) The northern boundary was digitized to the abandoned Seaboard Coastline Railroad. 4.) They were both digitized at 1:5000 off the Charleston county GIS parcel layer.
